One of my top two Ramen places. Great noodles and broth. My kids love their fried rice. A must go to if you are in LV.

This is my favorite ramen joint hands down. I freaking love this place. They make their noodles, their spice level does not let me down, and their service is amazing. I come at least once a week and it's such a nice meal to have. I always get the shoyu medium ramen and a fried rice cause their fried rice is bomb. I'm always bringing a different friend so they can experience the ramen goodness as well. If you're reading this, I'm probably there right now.

I absolutely love the Monta on Spring Mountain. I won't be back to the one on Durango. My Tonkotsu Ramen was so bland I honestly think it was likely water I received for some reason. I wasn't checked on until someone brought a check. The employees sure were having a good time.

This is hands down my favorite Ramen spot in the city. I adore their spicy tonkotsu and, although it's additional, I like that they have fresh spinach on the menu. My companion ordered the chicken ramen was just as impressed. They are, however, closed between the lunch and dinner hours so be aware prior to your arrival, call ahead if you're unsure.

Easily one of our favorite places to eat in the Southwest!

Pros:  flavorful menu, reasonable prices, fast service(got our food in less than 10 minutes after ordering), noodles made in house and convenient location(just south of the 215 on Durango)

Con:  it's a small place and busy so you might have to wait a few minutes before you sit

Definitely a must try place if you like ramen.  You won't be disappointed!

Every time I come to Vegas. I enjoy all the different Asian food. My buddy is a local and always takes me to the good spots. Vegas some of the best Chinese, Korean Vietnamese and Japanese food far away from the strip.

This Ramen place was great. I have had better tasting broths but this one is definitely tasty. I got double  order of noodles and meat. I was stuffed with the noodle portion that it came with but I definitely took it with me and ate it later.

This broth had a creamy red look to it depending how spicy. It was a little thick for me. I got hot and it was fine. 

I was not too crazy about the meat (pork). I like my pork crispy/pork bellish. This was round cut slices that had a weird texture. Don't get me wrong I ate all of it.

Did I mention noodles made from scratch!

Definitely a place to try if you are in town. As always it fits my requirements, whole in the wall and lots of love in the food. Small place with an open kitchen, serving it quick.

I would say I go into this southwest feeding ground about once (more like twice) a week. It's a small location, that usually takes awhile to be seated but is always worth the wait. Usually there's no upsides to sitting in a cramped corner, watching others get seated before you, but here they have set-up a large window to allow you to watch an adorable older woman hand make the noodles that go into every dish. They take, "The way mom use to make it." seriously here, because mom is STILL making it and you can taste her love in every bowl.

This girl version of a bachelor, really enjoys her take-out food and this place tastes just as good when you're dining in as it does in a huge bowl being eaten on my couch. My only issue is time and time again we have a disconnect in ordering and some extra topping I added is typically missing. When I'm there they are really good about bringing it out to me quickly, but when I get home there is nothing sadder than adding all your fixings and you realize that your Nitamago (soft boiled egg) is missing. The eggs aren't the only things that are extra when you go there though... Yes, I am referring to myself as extra.

Extra (definition found on Urban Dictionary)

Doing the absolute damn most, for no reason.

My order in order:
1.) Broth
-Miso Ramen (pork & chicken broth)
2.) Spicy Level
-Medium, even though sometimes medium feels a bit more on the hot side
3.) Extra Toppings
-Nitamago (soft boil egg), for something soft in texture
-Bamboo Shoots, for something crunchy in texture
-Spinach, for something green
-Corn, because I love corn in everything
-Butter, because carbs

The real secret to amazing ramen is you MUST add the Black Garlic Oil, because my ramen can never have too much sodium. I'd get it on the side though, so you can add to your liking.

Yep still 5 stars.  I had the Tonkotsu Ramen this trip which was amazing!  The pork broth was delicious and had a slight creaminess to it. I enjoyed the roasted garlic cloves, kikurage mushrooms, and green onions.  

I also tried the fried rice this trip which was also very delicious. Great ingredient ratios and fantastic flavors. 

Next time ...Pork Belly bowl!

Excellent fresh ingredients, however small portions and an extra charge for small pieces of chicken instead of pork (their main ingredient in everything) really hurt this resturants ratings review... $50 bucks for 2 adults and 2 kids is a bit much  for ramen especially if the youngest is 7 and doesn't order a main entreé. I would consider going back if the menu changed and had more none pork options without the price hike. I wouldn't mind paying for fresh ramen fully loaded for around $10. Also, The drink selection sucks and over priced. Let me know when you change this, I'll come back and change my review.

When you walk in, the first thing you see is a pasta machine for the noodles which is awesome because you see it being made. It's way smaller than I expected. I wanted beer but they didn't have the beers yet. Why would you open without having all of the products that are on the menu? Whatever so I had a Coke. Let's be realistic here, a can of Coke does not cost $1.25. At Monta (same owner) it's only $1. It's .25 cents more but that .25 shows a lot. Very easy menu to me so I love that. Not too many options so you're not stuck for 20 minutes trying to pick what you want which is awesome because you turn over tables faster. They don't have gyoza. This is the first ramen place that doesn't have gyoza on the menu. I got the chashu bowl and asked for it with extra sauce. The server said okay and my man ordered the pork belly bowl with extra sauce. They came back without sauce and were so dry. The pork was dry and my chashu was really delicious. Just too try. Apparently they don't come with sauce. Then don't say okay? I understand that it's their second day but that's so obnoxious. Learn the menu before opening. When he told the manager and server about the dryness, no apology, didn't comp it off, and nothing. All she said was that it's their second day. Congrats. It's a restaurant. I had eggs in my ramen but they came on the side even before the ramen???? You could've waited to put it in? I don't know. The food was fine but not to my standards.
This place was fantastic! They make their own noodles and the prices are super reasonable. Also, very accommodating to vegetarian and vegan needs.

Depending how you enjoy your ramen, this place has a spice level added to it, but can also order original, to get the taste of the soup base. Visited Ramen Kobo on a Saturday evening around 6:30 and there was no wait at the time, but as it started to get busy right after we ordered, so be cause to come early if you can. There are bar seating and table seating. Bar is good as you can watch the chef cook. We ordered a chicken soup based and a pork soup based Ramen, with a medium spice level to both and a Pork belly rice bowl. All were very delicious and everything comes out super hot! I would have liked to taste the original just to taste the flavors of the soup without any spices added.... Great food and definitely coming back next time! RAMEN IS GREAT!!!

This place is always clean, the food is delicious,fresh and authentic and the service is always great! My favorite dish is the fried rice  and the chicken ramen  broth with vegetables and egg  extremely good

I've been to a handful of ramen restaurants within the past 2 months & this place by far have been my favorite.  You can taste the difference in their noodles (probably because they make it themselves at the restaurant).  I also really like their fried rice.  I don't like spicy food but their kimchee fried rice I can handle.  It's not too spicy but still has enough kick for my hubby to enjoy also.

My friend recommended this place to me saying their ramen was amazing, it certainly is. I had the chicken broth ramen with the fried rice, my husband had the pork one and both were delicious. The setting is warm and cozy, not very big. The service could have been a bit more attentive but then again we went on a busy night. I didn't finish the whole plate, it's pretty big portioned, so I took it to go. Will definitely be visiting again!

Wow. Just wow. 

Best ramen I've had. I got the miso with added egg and corn, hot. It was pretty spicy but delicious. My boyfriend got the spice under hot, mild I think. And it was really mild, not much heat at all. The noodles were thick with grate texture. The broth was divine. 
We had the pork and chicken buns, they were mediocre. It's the sliced meat they put in the soup with some lettuce and mayo I believe. 

The employees all welcome you when you enter the restaurant. Service is fast and friendly. 

By far my new favorite spot.

I just moved here from Los Angeles so I have been trying out a bunch of restaurants  in my area. I'm glad I tried Ramen KoBo! The tonkotsu broth was de-li-cious! The broth had an intense pork flavor that was rich and buttery. The freshly made noodles were perfectly cooked. The cha-siu pork was so tender it literally melted in my mouth! I have frequented a lot of ramen places in LA, OC and now Las Vegas and Ramen KoBo is easily one of my top ramen restaurants. 

P.S. My fiancé who is not a ramen fan at all ended up loving this place. It's just that good!
This is our second time here. If it's busy the waiting sucks but it's well worth it. The fried rice is also a must

So my verdict is in. I waited to write his review after my second visit, because I just wasn't sure on how I felt about their ramen. First, their ramen is mediocre at best, truthfully, the broth was very bland to me. Also the claim that they hand make their noodles is nice, but it definitely doesn't taste as good as places that don't hand make their noodles. I enjoyed their chashu fried rice and their service though. Ramen isn't really their strong suit in my opinion

My cousins introduced Ramen KoBo to me and I went to Heaven 

The Tonkatsu was pure bliss! The pork melts in your mouth and you can tell when you get that FRESH ramen noodle in your soup. 
The kimichi fried rice was very tasty and not super pickle-ly. There's a delicate taste of kimichi into it, which is just pefrect.
The Pork Belly bowl beats Monta by far! They simply make that pork and steamed rice with love...  
A week after Ramen KoBo's experience, I went to Monta to check the hype of it... never going there again! I'm definitely a KoBo snob.

Excellent traditional Japanese Ramen shop.  Had the Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen with fried rice.  The place is small, only    a few tables inside and the line can get quite long because of it. Try going at off hours and go in small 1-2 person parties to get a table faster.

Had a late dinner here tonight. Ordered a vege ramen and a shoyu ramen with extra chashu pork. Both had the mild spice level. We thought the ramen was very very good. Nice flavorful broth. Spicy level was just right, and could taste the food (unlike some, where it's so spicy, that's all you notice). Some people might think the shoyu ramen looks a bit oily, but I thought it was ok. (Maybe if you let it go cold, you could see the grease more - no chance of that for me - my bowl was gone like that!) I was a bit disappointed with the lack of hot tea (warming up canned tea doesn't count). I would recommend this place though, and am looking forward to trying some of the other ramen dishes.

I thought the ramen here was authentic tasting but didn't quite do it for me to be honest. Sometimes when it is so fatty, it leaves this film on your lips. The fried rice was delicious and so were the pork buns. I wish they had dumplings or other small appetizers. It would also be nice if they had a bigger restaurant! I can only imagine how long the wait is on a weekend with this place only being able to seat like 20-25 people

My fav local ramen spot! Jinya (probably the most popular ramen spot in LV) is honestly overrated, but it is better for group outings. Whereas KoBo has great authentic Japanese decor, but is unfortunately a very small restaurant. 

I personally enjoy ordering takeout, as it's just as good when you enjoy it in the comfort of your own home, but without the wait and cramped feelings. 

I love how you can adjust the heat to your preference, 'Hot' has my heart. 

PS don't forget to add an egg!
Oh so tasty ramen because it's freshly made. I will be a regular customer here for sure. The setting and ambiance is really just like a Japanese restaurant...very nice!

My friend and I were starving and didn't feel like driving too far to get food. Ramen kobo was about 1 mile away !! 

We got there around noon, and the restaurant was halfway full and getting fuller. I was starving so we ordered right away. The waitress took our order wrong and we ended up with an extra noodle which we gave back. I ordered a tonkotsu ramen extra spicy with a soft boiled egg, and we split a small fried rice. 

The tonkotsu ramen was super tasty !!! The soft boiled egg was plain but it was nice and soft, I was hoping for an ajitsuke tamago egg. Ordering extra spicy was a good choice, it was pretty spicy and made my mouth tingle. The fried rice here is bomb!!!! It's super flavorful, next time I would order a large so I could have extra to go.  Food is decently priced as well, I would come here again if I was craving ramen.

This is my third time here, and I love that they are consistent.  The pork broth ramen with medium spice is my favorite. With a side of fried rice you just can't go wrong.  
The service is great and everyone is so friendly.  Tu better believe I'll be back!
Best ramen in town  and so convenient for southwest area I love it and very fast serving

The restaurant is very small. We are a family of five and had to squeeze into a table that was only made to seat 4. This was to avoid having to wait longer and the hostess was kind enough to ask first if it would be ok (2 adults 3 kids). With that being said, the menu is very straight forward and service is fairly quick which helps minimize the wait time for other parties. 

As for the food, I've tried the Tonkotsu and the Miso. Both were flavorful and in my opinion, was served with a good ratio of broth to noodles. The noodles are made fresh of which you have the opportunity to watch as they are being made while you wait to be seated. The meat portion is rather small and have to pay more if you would like to add extra toppings. This will bump up the base price of the ramen another $1.50 to $2.50 for each item you add on.

Overall Ramen KoBo is very good with friendly and fast service. I will definitely return especially now that winter is right around the corner.

This is one of my favorite ramen places now besides Monta Chaya. But I probably love this place more because there's not a long wait time and they have spicy levels!

As someone who loves spicy food, I eat my ramen with the level fire all the time. If you can handle really spicy food then fire will be nothing to you. I also love how flavorful and fresh their ramen is. Every time it comes out, it's always super hot and fresh, never lukewarm or anything like that. 

Service is also very nice. The place can get busy but even then, the servers try their best to check up on you, refill your water, etc.

The only problem with this place is that you can not substitute what you take out from your ramen for more of something else. You can only add extra which will cost about an extra $2 for each topping. I don't like bean sprouts or ground beef in my ramen so I always sub it for an egg and more chashu since you only get one piece. My bowl ends up being around $14. 

However, since their ramen is so delicious and their wait time is never over 15 min or so, I will always come back to this place. Especially in winter!

I'd be pressed to say that the ramen here is even better than ramen you eat in Japan. Seriously!

Ramen KoBo is by the same makers of Monta Ramen and you can really see the similarities from the dinky dining area to the limited but extremely well executed options on the menu. Fancy seeing the noodles made in person? The kitchen area is open alongside an end which is divided by glass and you can see the chefs and cooks spinning up flour with their hands to make the noodles.

I love this place for two reasons: first reason. EDM all day, everyday. And I'm not just talking about the generic big room stuff. No, this place was blasting oldies but goodies like Tritonal's Now or Never and new tunes (as of 12/7) like Illenium, Borgeous and more. Whoever decided to play edm, GOOD edm here, kudos to you.

Ok for my second reason, the menu items like I mentioned is limited but it is very good. I had the miso ramen with extra pork and an order of the boiled eggs. But one little thing that made a WORLD of a difference for me here...you can adjust the spiciness here. If you're a spicy food lover like me, this is a game changer. Seriously, I never knew miso ramen tasted this good when you make it spicy (going for the hottest one next time).

Not only that, but the broth is not so fattening and you can clearly see how smooth it is once you are nearly done with your bowl. When all your noodles and veggies and things have been eaten away, your broth will either have fat bubbles floating around or it'll be clear. All clear here.

I absolutely love this place and the best part is that it's literally three minutes away from my new office now. Win win win.

The service was really nice and the food were aesthetically pleasing to look at, but the taste did not match up. The food itself were a bit lack lustered in taste. Their broth were really light and overpowered by the toppings. I would rather go to Jinya, Marugame Monzo, or Ramen Sora

I was very excited that a Japanese Ramen restaurant opened on the southwest area. I love Japanese ramen and haven't had the the kind of ramen I had in San Francisco Japan town. My husband and my 3 kids ordered shoyu original, tonkotchu hot, pork belly bowl, and fried rice. I was a little skeptical about this place because of the yelp review I read before we went. However,  surprisingly they were very tasty and not even fatty at all unlike the review said. The portion was good and the freshly made noodles were cooked just right. The broth had plenty of flavors and clean taste.  I thought they were as tasty or even better than the ramen I had in San Francisco Japan town.
My kids loved the noodles and fried rice and asked me to come every day... :P

My fave ramen spot! Wait can be a bit long just like many ramen restaurants because of the limited seating. But everything about this place is awesome! Broth is exceptional! And, they have the vegetable ramen! Always satisfies my ramen cravings!

First time here and it's a very new place so I'll be a bit easy about it.

This is a small ramen spot by the west side.

I ordered a mild miso ramen with butter.

The ramen in general was good. The broth was a bit salty and too rich for my liking. I would skip the butter next time. The chashu was soft. I wish they added more bamboo shoots and bean sprouts 

I was with 6 other people and 3 orders were messed up. Hence the star I'm knocking off.

There's room for improvement but this place is still new.

Edit: I was typing this last night while we were waiting for our check and I'm knocking another star off because two of the waitresses kept asking my friend about his one can of coke. One waitress kept asking if it was just "one coke" on his receipt about 3 times, arguing with the waitress about it. We were all so confused and annourf because we were all talking and getting interrupted by the SAME question. It's like they didn't believe us about only getting one can of coke. 

So 3 stars for decent ramen but if you can't even keep track of one can of coke, there's some more training to be done.

I ordered the pork ramen without any add-ons. It was pretty delicious, however, you are better off ordering an additional pork slice into the ramen to give it a bigger boost of flavor. Also don't sprinkle too much of the red powder sauce into the ramen, I almost choked to death.

Out of all the ramen places I've tried, this one has got to be one of my least favorite. I gave this place a try twice and just came out disappointed in both occasions. I ordered the regular tonkotsu and the soup is just so bland for me. One thing I love about this place though is their fried rice. I've ordered those on both times I went and I have nothing but praise for it. It's very fresh and the rice isn't hard or too sticky, just perfect. It's a little unfortunate that I didn't care much for their ramen because their customer service here is fantastic.

VEGAN RAMEN option for the win!! We came one night around 9 and It seemed a little busy and... intimate. It isn't a huge restaurant and the seating was limited, but very comfortable. The hostess was friendly and sat us right away. 

They have a small beer menu, no wine though. We ordered our ramen with all the fun fixes! It came out Fresh, hot, and spicy! Did I mention they make their own noodles?! The portions are big! We had plenty of left overs which tasted great the next day! The price is fair and I will definitely be returning again... especially on the bone chilling days of the coming winter :)

My husband and I literally come here 2-3 times a week that is how amazing it is!! We love ramen and we love trying new places but ever since Kobo opened we can't go anywhere else. 

If you like spicy thank you'll love it here! We've been back to other places and still doesn't compare. But we both love it spicy. I know some say Monta has better flavors but to each their own. I can't believe I haven't wrote a review on this place but here it is. Just amazing!!

I really love the simplicity of their menu, its so approachable! Perfect for Ramen Newbies. The step by step process takes the guessing out of the equation and ultimately leads to you getting your food faster and their tables turning. Win-win. 

I dragged my guy over from cafe rio and into Kobo because a little birdie told me that they make their own noodles! The quality really shines.

We started with chicken steam buns, I could eat 10 of them they were so tasty! Perfect bun, crispy chicken light dressing.

For the ramen I opted for the vegetarian option while hubby went with pork and added ground chicken. Even at opposite ends of the spectrum these bowls were equally balanced, savory and most importantly everything was fresh. Next time I think I'll add black garlic. 

Mild is medium here so start at a lower level- you can always add more spice! 


5 stars for quality, freshness, ambience and customer service. I'll be back.
Omg fresh noodles being made as you walk in the door. Small place just like it's sister restaurant Monta. Nice people and service. Really nice interior. Will report back after I eat.

This is the only ramen place I've been to and after eating there it will probably remain the only place I go. I absolutely love this place and go at least once a week! The shoyu hot with one egg is delicious and my usual. When I was on a vegan kick I ordered the vege ramen hot no ginger with bamboo shoots and bean sprouts and it was also delicious but very different flavor and much lighter than the shoyu. Small place but fast service and worth the wait if there ever is one. Very convenient for calling in an order to go or placing one on the iPad up front. Will be picking some up tonight!

I'm not entirely sure what the hype is about this place. My boyfriend and I were not impressed at all. Both my boyfriend and I experienced the same problem with our bowl of ramen. The biggest problem was the broth, the heart of ramen is the broth, it was more like miso soup, it definitely lacked a real broth taste. The broth contained very little meat and was not prepared properly. Our eggs were cold, our pork slices were cold, and the fact that they add ground pork (cheapest meat you could add) which makes the dish completely undesirable. There is a ramen joint not too far from Ramen KoBo that offers 2 slices of beef, 2 slices of pork, one huge ox tail, an egg, and two seaweed wraps for less than the price we paid for at KoBo. The straw that broke the camels back was paying $3 for both of us to enjoy a cold egg (smh). This should already be included in our ramen bowls. We both definitely do not plan on ever returning. We gave it a shot and it definitely did not meet our expectations.

Definitly a place to go for a Hot ramen!!! Ordered shoyu mild. Destroyed in two minutes. 
Extremely polite employees, great service, and overall tasty ramen!

Cashu bowl is good. But a short hair comes out from ramen. And the server never apologized, and even asked me if it's my hair. Well.. Since I have a long hair, definitely was not mine. :( Additionally, i ordered mild miso ramen, and it's no flavored and too watery. So i asked for chili spice and they bring me chili oil. But it was not even spicy! They brought me A REGULAR SESAME OIL!!!!!!!!!!! HOW AWEFUL.  I will never go there again.
Love this place!! Their fried rice is amazing!! The ramen is my favorite :) The staff is so welcoming and friendly even when it is busy!
All I can say is YUM.  Great place for a quick and delicious meal.  Service was fast and nice.  I will be coming back and you should try it.

BEST PLACE EVER! Such a great experience. You can watch the ramen noodles being made, the ramen soup all around is amazing! Perfect amounts of everything in your soup. I will definitely be going out of my way for this ramen. I'm obsessed!
One of the best spots in Vegas. They have the best flavor in town. Small location sometimes the wait can be long but it's worth it. Great ramen spot
I went for a tad bit spicy instead of mild for once and was please rly surprised. Very good bowl of noodles. Always stop where when I'm in town for work.

Not sure what is happening to this joint, but the first time we tried their ramen, it was actually bomb. However, during our recent couple visits, the food seems to be a little cold. The chashu pork was still kind of frozen, the broth was at room temperature, and my husband found a whole chunk of garlic in his ramen. The garlic stalk was still really raw. It was like chewing grass. Lol. The taste was still good, but the quality is kind of deteriorating.

I felt so gross after eating here! I couldn't even finish my bowl. I had the Shoyu Ramen and the little chunks of fat in the broth completely changed my mood of the meal. I really like two other Monta locations a lot, I prefer them over every other ramen place in the city. This place was just dissapointing. They only have fried rice as side dishes and use one type of noodle verses thin/thick. 

 It's more expensive than other two Monta locations (sister stores) as well!!! There are better options than this place!
Really good ramen by the same owners as Monta. Not much for appetizers but the reason for coming to a ramen bar is ramen. No fuss, delicious and quick.

Pretty good, I ordered to-go the miso ramen with extra chasau and the kimchi fried rice. I didn't get any spice because I wanted to compare to Ohjah down the street.  I don't know if its because it was a to-go ordered but all the noodles stuck together when I placed them with everything in the bowl. I had to break them into short noodles since they didn't unwind. Also since it was my first time I was expecting the egg in the ramen, should of read the menu closer. Overall good flavor but I just prefer Ohjah a few doors down if I'm going to pick up food on this side of town. If you are dining there, this is place is super small like Monta before they remodeled.
Delicious Ramen made on site, the pork belly is perfection. I wish the hours were more accommodating throughout the day but other than that you will not be dissapointed.

I've been here twice now. I don't think it's all that good. Had the Tonkatsu Ramen and the broth wasn't flavorful; it was merely spicy. The fried rice came out a little cold and was just OK. There are definitely better options in Vegas.

This review is primarily based on the inconsistency in the food. I consider myself a regular here. They just added something new to the menu called tsukemen. I've ordered this dish about 3-4 times now and let me tell you it was nothing short of amazing. I enjoyed it so much that I even had to get one to go to eat later. Keep in mind this was made by what I think is the owner? I ordered my regular today and I didn't recognize any of the staff. I regret coming here today. It was absolutely terrible. The first taste of the sauce reminded me of spicy charcoal. Complete garbage. I am not hard to please when it comes to food but the dish was so horrendous that I had to stop eating it. I told the server how bad the dish was and all he said was "oh.. sorry.." with a smile and walked away. I hate to say it but just based off of this experience, I may not come back here.

SERIOUSLY OBSESSED 
.
**2017 Yelp 100 Challenge LV # 9**
.
This place is TINY but when I see tiny it means it's a smart business plan since they are using the space to the fullest. The place is simply decorated which is good when it's small. They can maybe fit about 25 people MAX!! 
.
The service is always fast & quick. This place is probably not like the most romantic place, more of like a quick meal & out.
.
-PORK BELLY BOWL $5.95 - it's simple & plain & I love it. Thin slices of PORK just cooked & topped onto a bowl of rice w/ salt & pepper & sesame oil. Topped off w/ scallions
 
-SHOYU SPICY RAMEN $8.95 - there has to be a bunch of MSG in this soup base because I freaken can't stop craving the damn soup! I'm not much of a ramen person since I prefer to just make ramen at home for convenience but the soup here I just love.

-MINI MENTAIKO BOWL $3.95 - I love MENTAIKO w/ some warm rice & a whole bunch of scallions w/ thinly sliced nor I. There's also some sesame oil on the side for you to add for yourself.

-KIMCHI FRIED RICE $3.95 - I would say this is like most mild kimchi fried rice I have had yet.
.
All in all I love the soup & the mini bowls... nothing super exciting but it's convenient for a quick bite when you just want something simple. Plus I work close by.

For some reason I was craving ramen and what do you know, we were about to pass it by. We stopped here and luckily there was no line. It was really nice and cool inside.  I ordered the tonkatsu ramen which was with the pork broth and with a mild spicy level.  

My husband ordered the miso broth one and it definitely hit the spot. The beers on draft here is cheap so we had a great dinner.  This is definitely a great spot to come to and its affordable.  The noodles were so fresh and you can tell it was homemade. This was a great first experience at this place!!!

Located in a strip mall on Durango, they have a good selection of Ramen. 
The chicken ramen minus the ground sausage? which has no business being in there. 
the staff is friendly and the service is quick. The best part in the noodles made fresh in house in the front of the restaurant, nice touch.

I have eaten many Ramen soup places here in Las Vegas and though I found some that are good some that are not so good this place by far has been the best I have had yet it was absolutely delicious. They make their own noodles as well which was pretty impressive and fun to watch.

So glad to have a ramen place so close to home. I ordered takeout. Went to pick it up and the staff was incredibly friendly and inviting. I absolutely LOVE the fact that they make their own noodles. Got everything home and really enjoyed both bowls. Chicken broth with a few different meats. All tasted great. I will absolutely be back!
The food is the bomb.com, service was good they are very friendly, for sure going back to this place again.

I'm thrilled that all these new restaurants are opening nearby.  We ventured into this local place and thought the place was nicely decorated.  A little small but nice.   I tried the shoyu ramen.   I thought the flavor was good but they were a little light with the protein.   You have to get the extra 
Protein topping for $2.50.   We've have been to a lot of ramen houses and this one was ok.

There phone doesn't allow anyone to be placed on hold. As soon as you can call them, it just gots to busy dial while they are on the phone with another customer. 

Finally got thorough after several calls. Went in to pay hopefully have my food ready but that wasn't the case. Took me 30 mins to get there and still didn't have my food ready. Waited another 20 mins and still wasn't ready. I got people ordering there and they got theirs before mine. My order was nothing but two orders of ramen and a fried rice. 

They are fast when you dine in but take off is the worst. 


Employees need to focus on the customers who were waiting the longest. 


Never ordering here again.
This place is sooo goood.. it's funny how i ask for medium spicy .. and i get super hot it's ok not complaining it's good tho.its by my home and good friendly greetings i get in and out...

We are so happy we took this advice from yelp and dined-in to this place. This place is awesome, I seriously felt like I was eating ramen in Japan. Freshly made noodles from scratch on my ramen, flavorful soup with fresh toppings, sesame oil flavor on their rice topped with pork belly. I thought the ramen here is the best ever. It cannot be better timing than having ramen on a freezing cold night in vegas. Wow I highly recommend this cozy place called ramen kobo. You cannot go wrong with your ramen cravings.

The food was amazing, but the lady was not accommodating to our needs. We asked for a booth and they sat us at the bar, which we were okay but not once she offered to give us a booth when one is available. She simple said booths are no option, and the restaurant was not even full on a Sunday night.

I believe this has been my 5th time here, the food is always good and the service is excellent. My server was really kind and genuine. I got seated really quick too even thought it was on a Friday night. Even though everything was great but the background music was really bothering me. The restaurant played Hardcore EDM which made me feel rushing to finish my food and leave. However, definitely a good place to try and you will like it.

Cleaness 5/3 , food wisely idk yet mine still on the way but i wonder what kind ramen without boil egg , $1.50 extra for egg ( over price to me ) and from my place i sit i can see man restroom open the door straight i can see ... Uugh !! Guess ... I ll be back to sora again . Staff is "pretty" nice so far .... 

This is my opinion i might be wrong but u guys can try your self .




Update : food wisely 5/4  fried rice lil bit dry , miso ramen not bad at all . Staff still nice
Wow. What a wonderful place. Small and clean. Great service. The food was excellent. The pork broth was on point. Noddles was fresh!!!

I returned to my quest to find the greatest ramen in Las Vegas this week. The specialty that I noticed at Ramen KoBo was the spice level. I love spicy so I naturally had to go fire for the level. I then went with my go to tonkatsu and added some spicy roe as I'd never seen that as a topping option. 

Price is the same as anywhere else in Vegas. I feel that the chefs have all just called each other up and set a price to $9 with additional topping prices varying. 

The soup itself was the spiciest broth I have ever had - fantastic. My eyes and nose were running which is what I hope for when ordering top spice level. The noodles weren't that great compared to other ramen spots and the chasu, though good, was portioned very small. The roe were quite a nice addition so I'm glad I added that in. It gave the dish a nice extra layer. This ramen also included some ground prom which I didn't notice at first but was good since it made me feel less ripped off meatwise by the lack of chasu. This ramen was smaller than most with less noodles as your typical Vegas ramen front. I actually like that better because it seems that most places waste the entire bowl on noodles and less on extras whereas KoBo puts more spirit into the variety of toppings. 

KoBo is the best spot in town for a spicy broth. It will fill you up but won't get you bloated. They have salmon roe which I liked but the noodles weren't the greatest. Overall it filled my ramen craving and would be my #1 destination if I'm looking to burn my stomach on tonkatsu ramen.

Amazing vegan ramen. I loved the chili sauce and that they offer to put it on the side. Loads of great extras. Noodles are made in house and they are delicious. Service was Great and atmosphere was lovely. Can't wait to make another trip.

This is really great Ramen. The quality is some of the best Ive had outside of Japan. My go-to is the Tonkatsu broth with sliced pork. The consistency of the ramen leaves much to be desired. I usually go with spicy but depending on the day the amount of spice will wildly fluctuate as will the amount of sliced pork you get. I really do love this place but it is a bit expensive for ramen. Other places will give you a few add-ons as part of the price of ramen but at Kobo you pay for anything extra. A bowl of ramen with 2-4 extras will run you $14-$16. If you order your food togo its usually done in 3-5 minutes depending on how busy they are.

Came to Kobo on their opening day for dinner. The restaurant was clean, and nicely decorated. When you walk in, there is a glass room where you can see the homemade noodles being made. A plus!

My boyfriend and I ordered the same Tonkotsu ramen with egg and corn. One of the bowls came out with the wrong broth, but they were happy to fix the order quickly. 

I would get a medium spice for next time (we could barely taste the mild). The broth was a little creamier than expected, but non the less delicious.

The restaurant was fairly busy with a 15-20 minute wait. The staff was very friendly and helpful. Would come again :)

Great job on your opening day.. And welcome to the neighborhood!!!

I will never be back. Busy and small environment but that is the least of my worries here. Let me at least tell you the good things: 
1) Noodles - Handmade right there and quite delicious. Great texture. 
2) Ground Pork - Flavorful and tasty. 
3) Mushrooms - Good texture. 

Now, this all sounds great to start but we are missing one vital component to ramen: THE BROTH. The broth had absolutely ZERO flavor. There was no salt on the table for me to add. As I started looking around I could see that everyone was adding everything they could to this broth. You need chili paste, garlic, soy sauce, etc. It is simply not worth it. It was very disappointing and turned me off to the ramen craze everyone is so gung ho about these days. I will try another place and see if I can be swayed in a more positive direction. I see a lot of people giving this place a positive review so maybe I am crazy but neither myself or the people I was with enjoyed it.

This is one of my favorite ramen spots in town. I always go for their Tonkatsu ramen with corn, egg and of course extra pork chashu! Having different levels of spiciness that you can choose from is nice too. Excellent service, staff are very attentive.
This place is excellent, having just come back from living in Japan I am so happy to find a place that taste almost identical to what we had there. The homemade chili sauce is fantastic!!!
Really good food. Fried rice and miso ramen 10/10. Only negative soda is caned so refills were not free.

Noodle factory ! Check out their fresh made noodles . Noodle lovers must try this place ! I had the ramen w/ shoyu broth medium spicy . The broth is delicious, pork , n ingredients tasted fresh. The menu doesn't offer a big variety but I do appreciate a restaurant that focuses on quality of each dish . I'll definitely be back. I would highly recommend this place for the following reasons ; good noodles, reasonable price, trendy atmosphere.

Came here for the first time tonight, the service was very good. 
Ramen came out quickly, I ordered miso ramen level hot. 
I asked for no bamboo shoots and add corn and nori. 
The noodles were PERFECT! all the ingredients were great and WOW was the ramen SPICY! Which I love! My only issue was the price of the add-ons, most expensive add-on prices I have seen yet. 
If they lower their add-on prices I'll make his a five star review. 
Oh, the place is small so don't bring a big group!
One of the best Ramen spots in Vegas!!! I got half pork and chicken broth with an extra egg. It was delicious. The fried rice was extremely flavorful. So worth checking this place out.

I thought it was just alright.

Ordered shoyu original, and I found the broth to be super oily. The noodles were just right; chewy and cooked al dente. It came with a lot of toppings (chashu pork, fried garlic, kikurage black mushrooms, bamboo shoots, green chives, bean sprouts, ground pork, shredded red pepper). I found the chashu pork to also be super fatty and the flavor was very porky (not fresh). There was barely any meat and that wasn't flavorful at all. 

I didn't get any of the rice bowls, but maybe those are good.

Sat at the bar. Ordered two ramen and two orders of small rice. I had the shoyu ramen and my wife had the tonkotsu. Both with nitamago and served at the same time along side the fried rice. The porkbelly bowl came a lot later. 

My shoyu turned way better than my wife's tonkotsu. I was able to just order my ramen with mild spice so it wouldn't be too spicy. Fried rice was your typical egg and pork fried rice. But the porkbelly, perfectly seasoned and they wasn't light with the sesame oil. 

Our server was really nice, polite. Food 5/5. Coming back for sure.

I have been wanting to try this ramen shop since it opened in my neighbourhood. Finally, I had a chance to stop by for lunch on a weekday.  I arrived around 12:30 pm and it wasn't busy inside. There were only about 10 customers inside.  The interior was nice and I took a seat at their bar.  I like to see the cook's skill in preparing the ramen.  But to my surprise all the cooks and waiter were Hispanics with the exception of the hostess who was Asian female.  Stepping into a Japanese ramen joint, I expected that the cook(s) would be Japanese.  Maybe I am just too traditional.  So, even though I was skeptical, I was interested to see how authentic they could prepare the ramen bowl.  I only order their Tonkotsu ramen as I wasn't all that hungry.  I must say that I wasn't impressed.  For $8.95 + tax, you get one small piece of char siu in the bowl and no ajitsuku tamago (egg). The broth was nothing special as it was not rich and creamy. The presentation was just meh.  

I wasn't too happy that I could not pay with a credit card as I had to spend over $10 to use a credit card.  When I left, no one said one word to me.  No bye, no thank you!?! This place is so not typical of a Japanese ramen joint, where their staff are usually very polite and thankful.  My verdict, I definitely will not be going back to this place.

They have a display right at the door to show that they make their noodles fresh. I think that is their selling point but I didn't taste any different except that the noodles don't stick together.  The broth is salty. The meat is thin. Compare to other ramen place, they are missing the usual toppings such as marinated bamboo and egg. To add one egg, it is $1.50 extra which bring one bowl of simple noodle to over $10. The place is small but with not too long of a wait.  This place is very average and the value is not good. I guess it is good for locals who don't like to drive far or wait too long. I will not come again because the food is very average and not competitive.

I love trying new ramen places and this one hit the spot. Despite craving ramen in the Vegas summer heat, this one here has a simple make your own ramen menu along with ready to order dishes. The flavors are more to my liking than I would say maybe Monta and Jinya combined. It's definitely a running up to Ramen Sora but it might just win for me since the miso with mild flavoring opened up the taste buds really well. You could add more if you want but it was the amount of flavors I needed. On the side I had chasu pork buns I believe which needed more flavor and chasu but the main idea of this review is definitely the ramen. I love the environment, it has the feel of what a ramen should should be and you can watch them make handmade noodles so you know the quality of the noodles are always fresh. It is a little far for me since I'm centered in the spring mountain area but the drive is worth it if you want a good ramen fix.
The ramen had good broth. Their bamboo shoots are really small but extra corn for 1 dollar is a lot ( I love corn ). The noodle is kind of hard but I think that's how it's supposed to be so it's ok.

This reviews coming from a person who isn't a ramen connoisseur but one whom enjoys it. For $8.95 + $1.00 egg add on, I ordered the hot spicy miso ramen. Pretty pricy for just adding on type of topping. It came with chives & pork chashu already. There was barely any meat, but I personally like the broth. I can see why people think it's oily. It had some flavor, hence me sipping it out of my
spoon more than chowing down the noodles. The in house noodles had a nice soft & perfectly cooked texture. Service was decent & the tight atmosphere made it all the more Japan-like feeling. Might be back!

I recently discovered this place which is only 3 minutes away from me. Their pictures looks great, actual food not so much. Especially spicy level HOT is nothing but super greasy. My favorite ramen places are near China town, so I don't like driving there all the time. I ate at this place for 4 times. The last time I ate there, I could sense they aren't happy with me most probably because I only tip around 18% up to over 20%. If you guys eat at Japanese restaurants, you'll know they are very welcoming, and everyone greets when customers are leaving, unless it's not an open kitchen. In this case, they have open kitchen. They greet people leaving the restaurant. I was not greeted at all last time, when I was walking out, two people was at the counter, only a waiter behind me greeted me. I went there earlier tonight, I already walked up near the kitchen where all the tables are at, they aren't busy, restaurant was more than half vacant. No one greeted me and the chefs were all standing there watching me, one fat guy looked pissed off at me the entire time, one lady was emotionless, one guy kind of smiled a little bit when I did. I've been standing there like an idiot, looking back and forth at these guys made me felt very uncomfortable, especially the fat guy, like dude, seriously?! That's how a 7 years old girl would act like if you get her mad. It was too uncomfortable for the way they were judging me, so I left. On the check, it lists how much to tip for 15%, 18%, and 20%. If you give the option to tipping, and I have been tipping within the tipping range, why have to be an jerk? I never tipped under 15%, even if I have, it is an acceptable tip. I like to leave changes so my bill adds up to full dollar. Looks like to me, the servers gossips to everyone there. Most of the Japanese people I met or seen are extremely polite, however all the chefs at ramen kobo are not Japanese, not all servers are Japanese either. I've never had this kind of uncomfortable experience in my life. I wonder if any customers have watched their reactions, WOW.... I would feel embarrassed for them. All the other Japanese restaurants I go to, the service are always consistent and super friendly. I was surprised with these people. I will never ever go there again. BTW, one of their server's breath is so disgusting! When he's standing next to me, I could smell his breath!
I read a three star review few comments below me, looks like this place's really got real shitty people, they are extremely rude. It's very uncommon in Japanese restaurants, it's jaw dropping for me. Very shitty place, most likely cheaper labor. What's your most expensive item? $10? LOL ramen kobo, you guys win on every level.

My family and I came here to eat for the first time and it was extremely crowded with little to no space inside, very small restaurant so I recommend not going during peak hours unless you have the patience to wait (dining in or to go). We decided to order to go and the process was really simple submitting the order on the iPad they have at the counter and took about 20 minutes for us to receive our food due to how busy they were. Everything was packaged very well.

Be careful with how hot you go. I warned my Grandma to get medium instead of hot just to be safe but she insisted and even though she really enjoyed it, it was a little too spicy for her. I was super excited to try this place because of the good reviews and with how crowded it was made me think I was going to love it. I ordered the shoyu (chicken) ramen and unfortunately wasn't thrilled at all. I didn't enjoy the flavor the only reason I think about giving it a second chance is because of how much my family enjoyed it.

By far the best Ramen. Hand made noodles, great flavor... you can't go wrong. Just what the doctor ordered for anyone under the weather and the perfect meal on a rainy day. If you're in the area, go! Check this place out!

Favorite ramen place ever! Their noodles are the best I've ever had. If you really pay attention to all the noodles at ramen places, then come here, you will definitely notice a difference! Their noodles are basically perfect and their broth is delicious! The staff is very friendly and their environment is so upbeat and positive! I love coming here :))
Great place.  I eat here once a week.  Pork belly over rice is great.  Takes a while to get a table but service is fast

I LOVE Ramen Kobo! I've been here about 3-5 times and it's always consistent! I love their shoyu and tonkotsu ramen. Their tonkotsu is more for people who like milky broth while shoyu is more for people who like flavor! Their noodles and ingredients are also super fresh! I like adding nori and egg to my ramen. Overall I love this place and love coming back even if it means waiting awhile for a table

(2.5 star)
Came here on Wednesday at around 11:45 am, right after they opened. There were already about 10 people eating (wow!).
I was exited to try their gravy like thick creamy Tonkotsu broth ramen. I ordered it mild. With extra chicken chashu(char siu), green onion and seaweed paper.
When it came out, I saw red spicy oil floating in my soup. I specifically told the waitress I wanted it mild... so I told her I ordered it mild. She tells me "Oh, we have spicy oil right next to our soup pot, so we usually put a little in. I can bring you plain broth on the side so you can put it in your bowl." WTH!! If I was sensitive to spicy, I would've sent it back. (Luckily I was a spicy food lover)
Tip... If you are sensitive to spicy food, tell them you want it "plain" instead of "mild". Their mild is like spice level 3 out of 10. 
Usually Tonkotsu ramen comes with straight al dente noodles in decent ramen shops but theirs come with freshly made non straight noodles. I could tell their noodles were very fresh. I enjoyed it. 
Though the soup was a little spicy, it was tasty and flavorful. I was expecting the soup to be much thicker but they probably over diluted my soup with hot water.  For some reason, my chicken chachu was ice cold like they just took it out from the fridge. I don't know if it was supposed to be cold?? but would've been better if it was warm or hot. 
Location is convenient right off 215 but if I want Tonkotsu ramen, I would go to Monta. 
Will not come back.
Absolutely coming back with my friends again....there Ramen noodles is super good! Worth to wait.

I'm a sucker for fresh noodles and I was told that they make their own here. I also LOVE my ramen spicy so I was eager to try this place out once I heard about it. The inside is really small but I love the simplicity of the design. It was pretty busy when I came here but the wait was surprisingly short.

I ordered the medium spicy miso ramen (should have gotten hot/fire). I didn't add any other toppings because I thought they were on the pricey side. Most of them are $1+. I thought the broth and the stuff it came with is comparable to the spicy ramen from Ramen Sora (ground meat, bamboo, etc). The broth is super thick and heavy, but delicious.

The staff was really friendly but once they brought out our check, I felt really rushed. The lady was about to take my bowl away before I even answered her question as to whether I was finished or not. I get that it's a small place and people are waiting but I'm a slow eater and don't like to be rushed.

Finally got to check out Ramen Kobo. The service is excellent, they're friendly and quick. Was a little surprised that they didn't have any appetizers on their menu. Usually Gyoza is a staple at ramen restaurants even in Japan. It's always nice to munch on Gyoza while you wait for your ramen. Luckily, the wait for ramen was really short. The ramen came out quickly and piping hot. I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen with soft boiled egg. The broth in itself was very flavorful though a little too thick in consistency for my liking. They only give one piece of chashu which was a little odd because most ramen restaurants give you a couple slices at least. The noodles were very good. They weren't too soft nor too hard. Love that they make them fresh in house. I also ordered a side of kimchi and it's the kind of Japanese style kimchi that I love so I gobbled that all up. They put on their menu that they include bamboo shoots in their ramen but they're very thinly sliced and sparse. I usually like the thick slices bamboo shoots in my ramen. 

Overall, Ramen Kobo wasn't bad. The service was very good and it's a good place to grab a quick bite to eat. Was the ramen my favorite? No, but I will bring my mom in when she comes to town to give it a try and see what she thinks. I just like the fact that they make the noodles in house, can't find that everywhere.
The broth of the Ramon is ridiculously good... But beware.. mild is spicy...but awesome...I had pork and chicken broth with added soft boiled egg...yummm

SO good and straight to the point. It's delicious ramen and that's it. 

They don't mess around with appetizers. You just get in, order your ramen and spice level and enjoy a delicious meal! 

Probably one of my favorite ramen joints in town. And the fact that you can watch someone actually make the noodles from scratch is very entertaining.

I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this place!

The Ramen I got was delicious, reasonably priced, and serving size was perfect for me.

The restaurant is SUPER tiny tho, so expect to wait a bit to be seated.

My cousin took me to Ramen KoBo one evening when I was in town visiting. They have both bar and table seating, but they aren't that big of a restaurant. Anyway, the night we went, we called ahead to check what time they closed, and they said they would be closing at 11 PM. It was around 9 PM when we had called. However, when we got there, they said they were about to close! They still decided to seat us, but just barely after we ordered, they were already shoving the bill at us, saying they needed to close the register. Why bother seating us then? Meanwhile, other customers that came in after us were also very confused that the staff were closing the place really early, and were given abrupt responses as well. 

As for the food, they have four different broths you can choose from, which include certain toppings depending on which broth you pick. Then you can pick how spicy you want your broth, and any additional toppings you want to add.The ramen we had ordered was good, but I cannot get over the rude staff. I don't think I'll be coming here again.

Messed up my order so waited forever and on top of that sat people before me even though I was there first.  Seems like srevers dont have their own sections so pretty chaotic.  People just running around.

Im a big ramen fan, but for $8-$9 for basic ramen there is almost nothing in it.  I rather them charge me more and at least throw in an extra piece of lettuce or something. Everything you add is an extra dollar, even for some extra hot paste and scallions.  Although broth is not bad.  Seating is pretty cramped and hot as well.  Not a great experience.

straight to the point review
been here maybe 4x already and was always happy upon leaving the restaurant.

**what i liked
broth (very rich flavors)

noodles

portion size

charsiu pork (very tender!!!)

staff are wonderful

**what i did not like
they only give you like 2 slices of charsiu pork on each order

very limited seats and place was too small

they charge a bit high for add-ons

no gyoza 




****ask for their roasted garlic condiment together with the pickled ginger

Our family loves this little hole in the wall place! It's pretty new to our neighborhood but it definitely became one of our favorite places to go to grab a bite. 
It's inexpensive. Cozy. Menu is simple but delicious! 
My son devours their fried rice and I'm in love with their soups with homemade noodles (you can see how they make them, by the way. Their noodle making part of the kitchen is right by the entrance behind the glass wall. Awesome idea)
You can choose how spicy you want your soup and they have great selections of add on items for it. 
They won't seat you unless you have the whole party present, but it's due to very limited sitting. 
Highly recommend it!

Amazing ramen place that handmakes their own noodles right in front of you! Just be careful trying to take a picture of them running the noodles through the machine - it can get a little awkward when they see you taking photos of the employees.

I got the miso ramen. The broth was very flavorful and full bodied, the noodles were perfectly chewy and al dente, and all the toppings were delicious. One thing that I missed though was a lack of vegetables and more toppings. You can add extra toppings, but they were a little pricey and I expected a little more to come with my bowl, especially for the price. 

I ended up getting the original spice level because I can't take spicy food, but my friends got medium-hot level and they were all suffering greatly. If you're a spicy noodle lover, this is a good place for you, but be careful of what level you choose as they can make it really hot!

One of my favorite places for ramen in Vegas! Definitely go here if you like some spice! I always go with mild miso ramen with a side of kimchi~ Even mild has some kick to it! Kinda on the small side space wise but so are the rest of the ramen places. Usually not too busy either which is nice! Definitely try this place out if you haven't already!

Excellent tonkotsu ramen with lots of fresh, chewy noodles, ground pork, and other components that add flavor and texture.  Fried rice also a favorite!  Great flavor and texture compared to "Chinese" fried rice.  I will be back.

It is located right in front of EOS Gym (the temptations!!!) next to Subway and Cafe Rio. 

It's owned by Monta but Kobo's ramen is a little different. It has bar seating and also a good amount of tables. I have never had to wait for seating so far. It has all the basic broths; miso, shoyu, tonkatsu and vegetarian. Then you are able to pick your spice levels and extra toppings. I always order the miso ramen anywhere I go and add the boiled egg. So good!

Now the miso ramen here comes with charsu pork slices AND some form of ground meat. Not sure if it's ground chicken or pork. Either way it's good lol. The broth has been a little too watery for my taste so I find myself adding A LOT of that orange ramen seasoning (which I still don't know the name of) and sesame seeds. 

Although I still like Monta just a taaad bit more, I like how this is super close to me and I can get my ramen fix without having to suffer going all the way to Chinatown :D

The fire ramen is nice for people who eat as spicy as I do. The pork belly bowl is bomb. We got it cooked crispy and I think that made it even more bomb. Lol I would definitely come back here. Super friendly staff. Thumbs up! Trust me, I'm picky about my food, this place is bomb. They also make their noodles fresh.
Love the soup.base, noodles,  freshness,  quick service,  customer service! Love how they are consistent and toppings are yummy! I like the pork chasu,  egg, butter,  and extra noodles!
Food is good comparable to Monta and Sora Ramen. Great prices great service and actually Asians cooking as well.
I never thought anyone could make a better ramen than instant shin ramen with an egg but this place was bomb.com

It's never a bad day for ramen at Kobo. Similar to ramen at Monta, but without the hard parking and ridiculous wait times. 

Ramen Kobo offers a few levels of spicy for those that love and dislike spicy food. Be warned though, I ordered medium and it was pretty spicy. Ramen at Kobo offers a nice experience because you get to see how the noodles are freshly made when you enter the restaurant. If you haven't had ramen, I would highly suggest trying out this place. 

The location is small, so big parties be warned. Further, the whole party must be there in order to get seated. If you're looking for to-go they offer an easy way to order by yourself at the entrance, and are often very quick with getting your order completed.

Great noodles! Had one fried rice, one miso, and one with chicken. Add the egg and be prepared for spice. Even the mild is very spicy and while the flavour is phenomenal, it picks a big punch. There was a very short wait to be seated - which was indicative of how good it would be - and they pack in the people for some ramen-licious yumminess!

Always a pleasure to come here! My "Go to" place for my ramen cravings. Great customer service and enthusiasm from Rachel (look for the blonde hair girl with big glasses) and Angel. Accommodation at it's finest 

Tip: I call it, "Karl with a K special": Pork belly bowl with fried chasu and sliced eggs on top. Let Rachel or Angel know and they'll be happy to make it for you!

The service was very unattentive here. The restaurant isn't very big and you're very close to people, but a lot of ramen places are like that. You can see them making the noodles themselves, which is something I've always liked. 

My boyfriend got the kimchi fried rice and it didn't really taste like kimchi. He asked for a side of kimchi and although it would have cost extra he decided to get it, but it never came.

I opted for the tonkotsu ramen. The broth was pretty good. It had a good consistency. With all the other ramen places, I'd probably just opt for one with some better service.

First off.. I really wanted to like this place. I was happy there was another ramen shop in our area of town, and couldnt wait for this place to open when I saw it was coming a few months back. When I called in I had to repeat myself about 4 times to the person taking the order. I understood though, as it was around the 6pm dinner rush. When I got there to pick up the food, there was no parking, so I had to drive around 3 times to actually get a spot. When I walked in there was no one at the hostess stand, except for a lady placing an order on an ipad. A sever came over and asked me " If I needed anything?", and I said yes, Im here to pick up an order. She walked away towards the kitchen for what I thought was my food, Even though there were 2 bags of orders on the counter directly behind her. Instead of looking for my food, she went to grab orders for people that were sat down. Someone came out of the back to the hostess stand about 2-3 minutes later and asked me what I needed... Again. I tell her, the first server came back and started to try and help me but ended up giving my food to another customer that walked in. Then she took it back and gave it to me and I paid.. The guy got upset.. even though I was there first.. and called me an a-hole as I walked out. To summarize, they are disorganized. 

The food was not what I had expected. I ordered the tonkotsu Spice level 4.. broth was like salted creamy water. The chashu I ordered was almost all fat, and you have to pay extra for sprouts and egg. My wife and son ordered the shoyu ramen, they were not impressed. We also got a small order of the fried rice that everyone has reviewed so much, and spoke so highly about... It had a distinct fishy taste to it. My son is sort of a 4 year old ramen aficionado. The kid loves it and is very vocal about what he likes and doesnt like about it. I have to go with his instincts and agree this is not some place I would recommend. Maybe if we all ordered something different, or we ate there it might be better. After the first time I dont know if I care to try that out.
Best ramen in town! Everything is fresh! Not like the other places I have tried where it tastes commercial. They make the noodles in the restaurant! Fried rice is on point! Can't go wrong here!

Yes! Good Ramen in the SW! Really good spicy Ramen! Ramen so GOOD!!!! So I've been here a few times since they opened, the Noodles are really good so is the amount of spice they put in the Hot 

  My only complaint is if you order the Chicken Ramen it comes with Pork Chashu and Ground Pork soboro (Damn pork allergy) so I have to specify NO Pork and have to add Chicken for an additional charge because they won't just substitute the chicken.. So their Chicken Ramen comes with Pork unless you pay more.... 

 All in all great food, cute cozy little joint with pretty attentive service, and no waiting as long as the Ramen joints down Spring Mountain.

First time and won't be my last!!! I love homemade ingredients and this is a NOODLE MAKING FACTORY!!!

I got the miso broth with all the veggies and some ground pork. Add a little hot sauce and you got your self a great meal, especially on a chilly night 

I didn't try but was eyeballing the girls bao buns next to me and look forward to trying next time

I'm a total fan of this place. We came here on a Tuesday night before watching a movie. The restaurant is a bit small so make sure you don't come during peak hours. There wasn't a wait when we got there right when it opened at 5 pm, but when we left there were people outside patiently waiting for their table. The food here was delicious, which is what I expected since they're part of the Monta Ramen group! I would definitely come back for the Ramen. 

FOOD: We had the Tonkatsu Ramen, which was phenomenal! The noodles were perfect. The soup was tasty and not too salty. I picked a medium spice level, so make The Chashu Pork was soft, tender and fatty. 

We also got the Kim Chi fried rice that was also yummy. I read other reviews saying it was a must-try, but I wouldn't consider this the highlight of the restaurant. I believe this place deserves a bravo for their Ramen! 

PRICE: Everything was less than $10. The bill for three of us was $40. It's a great value for delicious food. 

SERVICE: The service was great. Everyone was efficient and fast! When we asked the server for her opinion of the food, she recommended yummy dishes and was honest about the items she didn't recommend. The food arrived within a timely manner as well. 

Overall, it was a great experience and I rate this place 4 out of 5 stars. I would come back here to try the other ramen soups! 

Happy Dining, 

J Tran
The store says that their open and it is passed 1130 but the doors are locked. Just another restaurant who falsely advertise the times they are open

Came to Ramen KoBo with some friends after work because they raves about it.  I'm not a huge ramen fan, but I think that's changed now.  This place has the best ramen and their noodles are sooooo good.  I would highly recommend getting the black garlic oil with any bowl of ramen you order.  Service was good but had to keep asking for refills of water.  Overall, great experience and I'll definitely be back

Noodles are freshly made, delicious, & you definitely can taste the difference. Portions are a lot smaller than other ramen spots in town. So if you're starving I suggest adding extra meat, veggies, & noodles. The broth tastes amazing, just the right amount of thickness, not too salty, just perfect. This place is SUPER tiny (just like the portions, haha). Everyone is smushed together, but hey, try make friends! Definitely not a place for big groups or gatherings to go, but definitely a place to try!o
Service was great. Ramen gave me explosive diarrhe@h. Tmi, but if you want to spare your colon the pain and suffering.. be careful.

Small restaurant in south west. It was for me the first time  to try ramen.  The service was quick. I tried pork belly bowl + a pork ramen with some extra toppings ( corn , boiled eggs, chashu pork ). And it was great. Price is super affordable. I will definitely come back.  Just remember the restaurant is small and you might need to wait before getting seated.

Ramen KoBo (Translated to Ramen Factory) is a new ramen shop that recently opened in the Southwest of Vegas near Ikea. Ramen Kobo being owned by Mon Restaurant Group, I had expected a higher quality considering their other successful shops like Monta and Monzo.

Ramen Kobo is a small shop with mainly bar seating to overlook their open kitchen, then 5-6 tables along the wall. Servers were extremely attentive but there was one cook in particular who looked pissed off and didn't want to be there. I would look up and see him giving me an ice-cold glare and I had noticed he was eavesdropping to our conversation the entire time which I did not feel comfortable. My personal suggestion is to avoid their bar seating. 

I got to try their tonkotsu ramen and veggie ramen. Both were subpar in my opinion. Ramen were on the al dente side. 

Tonkotsu: Extremely light, flavorless broth. If you took a sip of their broth blindfolded, you might guess that their broth is hot water with salt. Chashu was just one paper-thin slice of fat with no meat on it. Bean sprouts were under-cooked and made me feel icky. 2/5

Veggie: Broth was still bland but better than tonkotsu. Two slices of fried tofu to substitute the chashu but these tofu will make you feel like you are biting into a dish washing sponge. I would still recommend veggie ramen over tonkotsu. 2.5/5

Overall a very disappointing experience. They just opened so I'm sure they are still working out their kinks but I don't see myself coming back here again.

Great small ramen place. Service was super quick. There was a bit of a wait when we got there  (a couple parties ahead of us) but they get service done so quickly that you really don't have to wait long. We also enjoyed watching the man make the ramen noodles. 
Oh! Also the buns were amazing!!
Excellent quick efficient service with really good food and spicy ramen and  vegetarian ramen options. The kimchi was delicious, their beer was nice and cold.
So yummy! Big serving size, choose your spice level, and noodles are made in house. Like any other ramen place, it is a small area, so beware of a wait if you come for dinner. Great spot!
Great !! Open till 11 pm ! Today I had tonkotsu ramen and it was delicious!! Before ramen was too salty but today was just perfect

Absolutely great experience and will come back my times! The ramen was amazing. My two boys, a one year old and 12 year old loved it. We tried the Miso broth and it was great. The fried rice was so good we ordered another one to take home. The service was great (Thank you Neil!) And we didn't wait long. I'll be back with my parents and in-laws soon.

KoBo gets all the hype for their house made noodles. I usually say ramen joints have good ramen and better appetizers and this is that to me. Maybe I need to try the non-spicy ramen but this ramen didn't do it for me. 

The ramen was good. It was a little thin and light for me. I like heavy milky ramen but that's a personal preference. I did do spicy with the ramen and it made it taste like a Coconut curry soup dish that is Thai and Laotian. The pork belly was okay and the broth itself was good.

The appetizers they offer are good to me though. My assumption with KoBo is that they are greeted towards an eat and leave type of establishment. They have a simple menu with a handful of appetizers and you just order, eat, and leave.

I give them kudos for staying open late for late diners. If I'm in the area I'll stop in for a ramen craving, but not driving across town. Solid place.

I've been here twice and I love the food. The taste of the broths are amazing and the noodles fresh. Love it with the spicy flavor and adding the pork. I also can't get enough of their pork fried rice very flavorful. The place is very small so if it's busy you will have a bit of a wait. I have also ordered food to go and that was done super fast. Definitely a must try.

As other reviews say, it definitely has room for improvement. 

Our server, Camille, didn't seem like she knew the menu fully, despite the fact that they only have few items on their menu. We had to repeat our orders several times, but without us having to actually point at the menu, she didn't seem to understand us. However, since it's a newly opened restaurant, that was not a big deal. 

The stars are for their food. Their broth is full of oil and fat. There is rarely any flavor a ramen eater would expect from it. Just refer to most of the other reviews, and trust me, they are not exaggerating. 

There are so many other choices in Vegas for ramen. I am just disappointed that the only ramen location in Southwest area is a place that I will probably never return to.

Line out the door worthy food. Family friendly. Amazing food as expected! Slightly updated menu. Fantastic food. Same set up as their other location "Monta". Friendly, helpful staff. The cool addition is fresh noodles behind glass so you get to see them make it! Fun for kids during the wait :)

Being a sister shop to Monta Ramen, I honestly came here with low expectations the first time I visited. Boy, was I so glad to be wrong!

Location: This is located in the southwest part of town next to Cafe Rio. When entering, you are able to see workers making fresh batches of noodles. However, the shop is very small. Aside from around 10 seats at the bar, there are only around 5 other tables in the rest of the shop. It is very tight with not much room to move around. They only seat full parties so be wary if you are bringing a big group. It will take a while to finally be seated. There is almost always a wait during peak hours, but I have never waited more than 20 minutes for a party of 2-3 because of how fast everything is.

Menu: The menu is short and sweet. You just choose your broth, spice level, and extra toppings you may want to add. All bowls of ramen come with Chashu pork, Kikurage black mushrooms, bamboo shoots, green chives, ground pork, sesame oil, and shredded red pepper. There are also other dishes to eat like the pork belly bowl and kimchi fried rice.

Food: Be careful about the spice! The mild spice already has some kick to it, so be wary of the spice level you choose. Broth is rich and has a lot of flavor, but is not nauseatingly fatty. The noodles are very thick and capture the taste of the broth very well. There is also a decent amount of ground pork and a huge slab of chashu. There is enough where you have some with almost every bite, but does not overpower the dish itself. The portions are very big for a price of around $10 without any add-ins. Thankfully, adding additional ingredients are for a reasonable price & I always leave the shop feeling very satisfied and full. I've been dying to try their non-ramen dishes, but I always end up opting for ramen last minute. Hopefully soon, I could break this curse and finally give them a try!

Service: Workers are very nice, prompt and accommodating. Food comes out fast and I don't think they have ever gotten my order wrong from the many times I've visited. I never felt rushed or pressured to leave, though they do a great job at ensuring wait times are not horrendous.

The quality of the ramen and the genuinely kind workers are what convince me to frequently make the 30 minute drive from where I live to eat at Ramen Kobo. This establishment deserves more attention than it is currently getting. I truly believe this is one of the best ramen shops in town!

This is probably my favorite place for ramen noodles. It is so amazing that every time I go there, there is a long line. It is a very small place with limited seating, but let me tell you, you won't be disappointed!

My favorite ramen restaurant in the city. I come to Kobo at least once a week and the staff is always friendly and welcoming. You really can't go wrong here whether you get miso, veg or tonkatsu. Make sure to add an egg cause that's the best part. You pick your spice level or leave it plain. If you're unsure of what spice you can handle you can always ask for it on the side and adjust the spice to your liking. This isn't really a long sit-down spot, more of an on-the-go lunch spot or somewhere to stop for a quick dinner. They serve canned teas, sodas, as well as draft and I believe bottled beer. No happy hour, but prices are so reasonable there doesn't need to be.
Best ramen in the city!!!! Super sweet set up!! They have a self service iPad fir customers and use iPads table side to order!!! Great service and amazing noodles!!!

I normally like thin noodle.  Noodle at Ramen Kobo is not thin, it means not my favorite, BUT it was so yummy and I loved it!  I tried Tonkotsu Ramen and the broth was so creamy and thick. You should add egg, it's super good.
Super tasty ramen.  Comes in several spice levels mild to fire.  I got hot and that was just about right.  Add egg & extras for a cost.  Very small dining area so be sure to come on off hours.

I'm a huge fan of both Monta Ramen locations, so I had very high expectations to try their new restaurant.  After trying it though, I would say don't waste your time.  The ramen is decent, but it is nowhere near the level of quality I expect from the Monta family.
The worst offense is the broth.  Whether it's tonkotsu, shoyu, or miso, they all have little floating bits of pork/chicken fat swimming in the bowl that are nauseating to say the least.  At Monta, you can tell they take the time to prepare the broth by boiling the bone marrow, which results in a creamy and consistent texture and flavor.  I feel like Ramen Kobo is simply cutting corners by adding extra fat to an otherwise unexceptional broth.
I give it two stars because the noodles and toppings were all great, but the broth ruined it for me and my girlfriend.

tl;dr
Go to Monta or Monta Chaya instead!  They're much better!

Yup! This place is now a favorite! Super friendly staff, really nice decor inside and best part is amazing food!

I got the tonkatsu ramen with a medium spicy. I added egg, corn and nori as well as a side of kimchi fried rice.
