I will always love monta but here you get their great food and a more relaxed atmosphere no lines lol at least not yet but they will come this ramen house is a winner all around and close to home you can't beat that.

Most Vegas residents aren't familiar with the Japanese chain known as Tenkaippin Ramen, but if you are, Ramen Kobo's tonkotsu broth is practically a dead ringer.  They totally nailed the unique, thick, gravy-like pork broth that made me feel I could've been at one.  There are a ton of people that love this, but I am not one of them.  Despite the noodles being decent and that one meager slice of pork chashu (don't bother with the chashu chicken) tasting good, this simply did not give me the "kimochi" I was looking for.    

For those that dislike the amount of sodium usually associated with Japanese ramen, both the tonkotsu and the light shoyu broth should please.  That 5000 mg aftertaste many experience often won't happen here.  I felt obligated to add spice, since it was something they push here, but it didn't improve much for me.  Order it on the side and do what your heart tells you.  Mine told me not to use it.  

It was strange that gyoza wasn't on the menu.  I asked and also overheard two of the neighboring tables ask as well.  Why not just give the people what they want?

In the end, it's better than Omoide, but not as good as Sora or Jinya.  One and done.    

2.984743874 stars

Best ramen place in town. Came here for the first time today cuz one of my friends recommended it. I got the tonkatsu ramen with soft spoiled egg topping. Man, it tastes so good. The broth is very thick and rich, exactly how it should be. Noodles are the skinny kind which they don't give you an option to choose though. Doesn't come with eggs if you don't pay for the extra topping which is $1.50. A little on the expensive side but totally worth it. Been to so many ramen places, even its sister place - monta, this place by far is the best.

Been eyeing this place for a while and had a hankering for ramen noodles one Sunday night.  As you walk in you can see someone making noodles fresh right in the window!  Seating was fast and we sat at the bar.  I ordered the miso based ramen with added boiled egg on top.  The broth.  So good.  Seriously.  Delicious!  All the flavors together, including the fresh ramen noodles was excellent.  My boyfriend ordered his with mild spice and be prepared, It was spicy.   I think it was reasonably priced at $8.95 and portions were plenty.  
Very friendly staff and service.  Can't wait to come back as I'm already craving it again.

I got the Vege Ramen and added chashu chicken, butter, 2 eggs and Nori. The broth was delicious. Everything was delicious actually. The only reason I give 4 instead of 5 stars is because the place is very small and the seating pretty tight. Luckily we had no wait but I imagine at peak times there's going to be long waits. Also, 8.95 is not a bad price but after the add ons, it quickly doubles in price. I will definitely be back but those are the only 2 things I would change if I could.

I was SO excited to try their vegan ramen but sadly, it was kind of a disappointment. 

We came on Saturday right when they opened and we were surprised that people were already outside the door waiting in line and thought this place must have some tasty ramen! We were seated right away and liked the design of the place - there was a ramen bar and the tables are pretty close to one another so heads up that you'll be getting comfy with other parties next to you lol. 

The menu also include fried rice bowls and the various toppings you can add to your ramen. The vegan ramen sounded so promising, especially after all the great reviews but now I'm thinking maybe it's cause they just opened for the day that the broth didn't get to settle? I'm not sure but it was SO watered down, to the point that I honestly thought I was just eating ramen in hot water. I had to add more salt and some soy sauce and even hot sauce to try to make the meal more enjoyable, but nothing worked. Our friend ordered the chicken ramen and also wasn't satisfied; there was just something about our broths that made the experience an unsatisfying one. 

We did enjoy the small bowl of fried rice but believe me when I say, it was definitely small lol. 

Overall, I'm not sure if it was just our visit but I really wanted to like this place and sadly, that just didn't happen.

As a lover of Monta, their sister ramen spot in the Southwest side of town didn't disappoint. Similar to Monta, it's fairly small without a ton of seating (4-5 tables to sit families of 4, and bar seating), and I've only had to wait at most maybe 30 minutes. 

Friendly customer service. 4 different soup bases: shoyu (chicken), tonkotsu (pork), miso (chicken + pork), and a vegetarian bowl. They all come with a decent amount of toppings, and you can also ask for extra toppings. You can pick how spicy you want your broth: not spicy, mild, medium, and hot. As for their extra dishes, I've only had their Pork Belly Bowl so far, and it was amazing! Delicious, salty pork belly on top of garlic rice. 

I've come here twice already, and I'm glad to have a good ramen spot so close to my house.

Who would have thought this would be a neighbor  spot walking distance from my home. It's small & cozy and reminds me of a type of restaurant you would see in San Francisco. It offers an open kitchen layout and clean, contemporary feel with wood & metal material throughout. There is a small room upfront where the noodles are made. Unfortunately I have yet to experience this but hopefully one day soon. 
Now onto the good stuff...the food! Reminder: I was never a true fan of ramen until I came here. I have now dined in twice and take out once. 2/3 times I have tried something different; the basic shoyu and today consisted of the miso. Their spice level has a little more kick than what you may be use to. I recommend sticking with mild and kicking it up yourself with the chili oil & powder they have. I am not a fan of the ground meat that is standard in the ramen. It's definitely a consistency thing but so much better without it. The noodles are indescribable and cooked al dente and have yet to experience anything other. 

The only problem I have...they do not deliver nor on post mates or uber eats! But then again ramen should be enjoyed at the restaurant. It's not the same experience when at home. 

For any newbies, give yourself some time. Typically there is a slight wait but turnover is quick. Don't get impatient. You will not be disappointed!

First time there today. I've been waiting for a "perfect" weather to pair with ramen so I waited for our long summer to be over. First impression was nice, clean and modern as this is a new joint but the smell was off. The smell was overwhelmingly stale and oily. My culinary "red-flag" went up right away from that point. Lunch was fairly busy but luckily we sat at the bar right away. Before I sat tho, I went to the bathroom to wash my hands. Both men and women bathroom had signs that said the bathroom is closed for some work or something. WHAT?! This is a brand new place practically. But I saw that the women's bathroom was open and no one was nearby so I quickly washed my hands (of course, with door opened with my foot propping it open. Didn't want to "scare" any female patrons there you know!) Anyway, the hallway floor was sticky which is a good sign that they don't have a good sanitary protocols. C'mon, they just opened the door like 30 mins before we were there. It shouldn't be that way. As I sat at the bar, the dirty hoods caught my eyes. Once again, this place being as new as it is, the hoods shouldn't be that dirty with oil and filth. Another sign...lack of proper sanitation and maintenance protocols. 

Next thing I noticed are the workers in the kitchen making the food doesn't seem to have much culinary training.I'm accustomed to and expect to see people behind the kitchen who knows about the food and have appreciation for the food they are making. I highly doubt any of the workers have any prior training in making ramen before they start working there. Their lack of professionalism and respect for the food they are making truly showed with the body language and filthy stuffs they were saying. Especially the heavy set guy was pretty vocal and non-stop talking fairly loud while making the noodle, I so wish he stopped talking to minimize spitting into the food. For that reason alone, I would not return to this place again since I felt the food isn't being made with proper sanitary standard. 

Our ramen took little longer than expected but not too bad. I ordered a medium miso and I thought it was quite spicy. My staffs agreed as one ordered hot (she normally order 8-9/10 at Thai restaurants) and the other ordered a medium miso too. Taste wise, I'd give 3 stars. The noodle, which they boast about making in-house with their own machine is nothing more than a show. Can we say Krispy Kreme??? It really didn't deliver anything extra. Portion is on the smaller size so I ordered a side of white rice. Sorry I ordered "white" rice, not stale "yellow" rice. Another let down!

The waitress was poorly trained or just don't know how to serve properly. I'd accept "unfriendly" but this older lady was on the "rude" side! 

Ramen is something I appreciate quite a bit. While being a rather simple dish, it's one of those things that's not only filling but emotionally "hitting the spot" type of food. Kobo is a prime example where a business person with no culinary training and no culinary appreciation for the food they deliver turns it into a "factory" to make money, not food! Their name is quite fitting...a FACTORY! Simply a place where they make things. No thanks kobo, I'll look for a place where they take pride in food they make, not just the $$$ they make!

New favorite! The place is very tiny so come early. We were a party of 6 and they offered us a table for 4. We were so hungry that we didn't mind squishing. They have different levels of spiciness to choose from. I got the  "mild" but in my opinion that could have been labeled "medium", so they run spicy.

The broth was really good and didn't have that "lard" after taste. Their chasu or pork was really good as well.

I definitely will be coming back!

How can people give this place a decent rating? I was craving for some late night ramen since it was very cold outside. I came across this ramen joint on yelp. I was very surprise on how they make their noodles hand made at the restaurant. I only ordered to go, the order was fast and simple through the phone. 

The lady was very nice to me and took my order very professionally. I came in about 15 minutes and it was already ready like they said. We ordered the Tonkatsu and Miso ramen. Both broth was very tasteful and i enjoyed it so much. I really want to come back and dine in next time. I think this will be my new spot for some mouth watering ramen for every night.

I love the ramen and fried rice here!  So yummy!  Best ramen in Spring Valley, maybe in all of Las Vegas.  The noodles are made in house!  After discovering this place we came back the next day for take out.

Came here for dinner with my fam last month. I ordered the Miso Ramen with a side of fried rice. Everything was good to the last drop! Now we're here tonight for round two!! It's a little small so you may have to wait to b seated, but you'll b glad u did. The limited seating is the only reason for not giving this spot 5stars.

First impressions: small place. The only place for me to sit was the bar. If I were with someone else, we would have had to wait. This is at 2pm, tail ending lunch. Service was quick. I ordered the chicken broth. It comes with all this stuff. Of course, step 3 is to add other stuff which I added soft boiled egg and nori. Mild spiciness. The soup looked oily when it got to me but I think that's where most of the flavor is. I had to REACH OVER this lady beside me to get chopticks and people kept bumping my back as they walked by the bar. So that was awkward. This was while I was eating. I don't think the people realized it because the space was so tight, but I definitely apologized to the lady beside me for having to reach over her for chopticks. The broth was mild, just like I had ordered, but I don't like it this oily. The FRESHLY made noodles are absolutely delicious. The oil kinda bugged me and I was wearing all white, so I was scared it would get all over my shirt. I also received my drink in a can, which I don't like. All restaurants should have their drinks on taThen at 2:25, they told me that they were doing last call. I guess they are only open til 2:30 on Wednesdays. Then reopen at 5pm to 11pm. Overall, ok service, great noodles, oily broth, but flavorful. Very squished and cramped inside. I would MAYBE go back.

This place is outstanding, I eat their Vegan ramen at least once a week! They make their noodles fresh and you can taste the love in every single bite! You can say I'm obsessed but try it out and you'll see why. On a side note I was completely against ramen before this place so yea it's THAT GOOD! Also everyone that works there is super awesome and they're open late!! The place is small but that kinda makes it more special plus it's just as good Togo!  I'm writing this review to kill time before they open...

We came to this place because it was open late in the area we live in. The guest service was ok at best. The food came out fast and exactly the way we ordered it. The full size rice order was small.  Over all, it was ok but there are better choices for Ramen in Vegas.

Came here for lunch on a Tuesday about 1:30p and was sat quickly. Food came out quick which was nice since I had about 30-45 minutes before I had to get back to work. I ordered the shoyu ramen mild and honestly I felt like the chili oil they used to spice it up really overpowered the broth. I will need to give them another chance and order it without spice next time.

I came here again at a less busier time and this deserves 5 stars. I have only tried the vegetable vegan ramen and it is so incredible. The soup and noodles are crazy flavorful.  It comes with a couple different vegetables like corn and spinach and also tofu. I really suggest coming on off times and not coming with a huge group or else you will have trouble finding parking and will definitely have a wait time. The service is fast and efficient i seriously recommend this place.
I didn't like this place to much as a ramen place... I liked the fried rice and that's it.

This is my favorite ramen place in Vegas besides Monta Ramen (same owners, btw, but different style of noodle). I recommend the Tonkotsu (pork) broth. You can also ask for whatever spicy level on the side so you can add it yourself. I always get mine with Tamago (egg) & sometimes butter

I like this place. Their homemade noodles don't taste that bad actually, good with the miso ramen I ordered. On the menu however, I wished that the ingredients stated in Step 1 said that beans sprouts in the bowl, but they didn't. I'm not too big of a fan of bean sprouts, so I would've asked to hold on that. Service was okay. The older lady was a lot nicer, while the younger lady there seemed like she didn't want to be there. I would come back though as the ramen is pretty good.

UPDATE: correction it does say bean sprouts on the menu, still docking off a star for the service there precious time

This restaurant was on the small side as there wasn't a big waiting area. I decided to order take out as there were 6 parties in front of me. When I took the ramen home I was pleasantly surprised with the Tonkatsu ramen. It was flavorful but a bit short on the fixings. The flavor of the soup was good. 
I really liked the man taking my order. He gave me a good recommendation of the vegetarian ramen. 
I would like to try the restaurant again before giving a mediocre rating.

Decided to try this small ramen spot located near our massage location. Small but clean. Greeted immediately upon entering. I tried the Shoyu ramen spice level Hot and also the Kimchi fried rice. Spice level was on point. Broth was tasty. Noodle texture was good. Fried rice was okay. Overall, had a craving for noodles and this place hit the spot. Service was good, but we had to ask to refill our drinks and we got our check up front rather than them bringing it to our table. If you're in the mood for good Japanese ramen near this area, this place will satisfy.

I had medium spicy shoyu Ramen. I added ground chicken and spinach. THIS HAS TO BE SOME OF THEE BEST RAMEN I HAVE EVER HAD. Which is a huge bonus because it's near my house, so I don't have to travel far for Ramen this fall. The base soup is layered with flavor. I can't wait to try other things on the menu!
Small place but cozy. Cool decor. You can see how they make everything with open kitchen bar. Fresh made noodle. No salt base broth. Vegan option.

It's just too too good. Can't even tell you how many people I've sent here and how many times I've been here myself. It's quick it's delicious everything is fresh. Las Vegas has maybe into a Ramen lover. They have a wide variety of different types of Ramen and I think I just talked myself into going there right now!

Went with some friends the last time I was in town. It is small and it is busy, but when you've got a good product it happens. I really enjoyed my spicy miso ramen and would definitely come back again. Solid ramen spot, especially for its location.

Weve been coming here since the opening day. My wife and i always like the ramen, except for one thing. Its this one server that everybody is complaining about who has the worst costumer service of all  the entire staff here. Shes loud and doesnt let you finish when ordering your food. Its like she will finish your order for you. What happen to listening to costumer 1st before you open your mouth. We love their ramen but we just have to deal with her everytime. Well i just hope that the management will sit down and talk to her or train her the proper way of serving costumers.

This is an update.  I was there with my girlfriend and this time i ordered the tonkatsu ramen with ground chicken spice level eight with extra chili oil and extra noodle.  She had the pork belly rice and kimchee fried rice and I was blown away.  We both agreed that jinya ramen has their ramen beat just by a little but I will say that it is still a five.  The ramen was nice and hot and with the extra ramen noodles I was still able to make a small bowl for her too.  Kimchee fried rice was almost on par as Komex kimchee fried rice but it was still really good.  The porkbelly bowl with rice was the best i have tasted in the valley.  If you are in the area I suggest to stop by.

Tastes like spicy water, no concept of salt. I ordered the veggie ramen, but even my boyfriend who ordered the spicy tonkatsu was furiously disappointed. Jinya is less expensive and their quality of food is far superior. Save yourself the money and trouble, and go to Jinya.. 

Also, as a vegan the veg ramen at Jinya is the holy grail.
Love it here.. I've been many times and have also gotten take out many times. Yummy and close by. Usually a short wait compared to Monta.

I was really excited when I saw this place open up! It's awesome and refreshing to see a place that makes noodles in house vs using the soulless mass produced noodles from country XXX.

I came in here one night about an hour before closing. The place was still banging and full of patrons. From the looks at the podium there was a mad wait list at one point. I was Flying solo I took a seat at the countertop. I actually enjoy sitting at the countertop as you can watch the "magic" happen. I was a little perturbed that the wait staff was more concerned about taking care of their closing tasks vs waiting on guests. I had to watch the wait staff team walk past me several times before I was able to get my order in. 

The noodle making stuff had been shut down for the day so that bummed me out.. I guess it's bad luck to make noddles in the dark. 

The ramen was a bit on the small side however proportionate for the price. I did feel that my original order was a little on this light side compared to my kaedama order. The first set of noodles were perfect. Just the right firmness and texture. The kaedama on the other hand was a bit overcooked and on the soggy side. 

The broth was nothing fancy decent but nothing to wow about. 

My visit here was a miss .. maybe it was the timing or maybe this is how it is here.. not sure.. the jury is still out.. 

Till then the choice is yours..
I highley highly recommend you try this place for your selves. You will be satisfied.  The ramen noodles are fresh and the brooth so flavorful.

I have eaten a lot of ramen in my life, but this place was pretty horrible! We were excited to see that a ramen place was opening closer to home. When I read that this was created by the Monta team, I expected the same delicious food and had high expectations. Unfortunately, this was absolutely nothing like Monta.

The restaurant is super tiny and I felt uncomfortable being very close to the table next to us. I ordered the original Shoyu Ramen without any extra toppings. It's cool that they make their own noodles, but honestly there was nothing special about it. They were too thick for my liking and would definitely prefer the noodles that are served at Monta. The Shoyu broth was disgusting! There was no flavor at all and I honestly felt like I was eating noodles in a bowl of plain hot water. The one piece of Chasu was 100% fat and most of the ground pork sank to the bottom of the bowl, making it hard to eat. Just Eww. I hate to say this, but I think a $0.25 instant ramen from the grocery store would have been better than this!! They also screwed up on the spice levels for others at our table. My husband ordered mild, but he said it was pretty spicy. Our friend ordered hot, but it turned out to be on the mild side. 

I am giving two stars because the staff was attentive, refilled our drinks quickly and took empty plates away as needed. I understand that they are new and still getting their act together, but I will not be back. The drive to Chinatown is worth it for good tasting ramen!

Miso ramen medium spicy is real good better than nyc ramen places. 
Mentaiko bowl was also good but too much rice vs mentaiko.

Mhm! This place is definitely a great addition to the Monta family. We decided to check out this restaurant based off a recommendation and were happy we did! 

I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen with medium spicy and a soft-boiled egg. The appetizer menu was fairly limited, but they did offer four different ramen broths, a huge variety of toppings ($$) and the standard pork belly and chasu bowls.

Advice: If you're a huge meat eater, order additional chasu. If you want an egg, get it. Need extra carbs? Get it! Your ramen bowl, even with the additional toppings, will still cost you less than a Bay Area ramen restaurant ;)

Pros:
- Spice! Mhm. If you're looking to add a kick to your ramen, this place delivers.
- Ground Pork was super flavorful.
- Noodles were chewy! 
- Clean restaurant

Cons:
- Service was slow for a non-busy time.
- Broth was a little too light for me. If I'm getting Tonkotsu, I sort of expect a super creamy and rich soup.
- Only one chasu slice offered, but maybe that was a good thing. It's delicious, but super fatty!

Overall, this place was decent and I'd come again. I still prefer Monta Chaya or Monta Ramen over this place. For about two people, we paid $25ish with tip and tax.

If you love Monta then there's no way for you to not like Ramen Kobo. The place is small just like Monta so be prepared to wait. We only had to wait for 15 minutes which was not too bad. The service is little to none. They seat and take your order and they don't come back until you are ready for your check. 

I ordered my favorite which is the tonkatsu with the soft boiled egg. The soup and noodles were on point like always. The broth was super flavorful and the noodles were yummy. I don't know if this is becoming a trend with noodle places but the soft boiled egg is cold and precooked before hand. Am I the only one turned off by this? I dunno, I just like how it used to be freshly made in most places. They have red ginger and garlic you can add to the ramen which makes it more flavorful. 

Definitely will come back since it's so close to home. Try the ramen spicy! It tastes great both ways depending on what you're feeling.

An authentic local ramen bar I can rely on for all my ramen needs! Being my 5th visit, I thought it was due time for one of these. I usually get the Tonkotsu mild, or medium - spicy (depending on how daring I am that day), kimchi rice and Asahi. 

Each time I visit I feel welcomed and never rushed. Service is prompt and dishes come out in a timely manner. Most ramen bars I've been to, servers are either new and can't handle stress very well... or aren't new and could care less about hitting the bare minimum of service. I feel like this spot hits all their points making it a pleasant experience.

I give it 4 stars only because I prefer having freshly boiled and yolk-y egg, but it's always cold in my ramen each time I go.. Anyway, try it yourself!

I just moved to the southwest side of town and have really been enjoying the food options over here. Okay, so I will probably be blasted for this, but I can't stand pho. Yeah, every time one of my friends hears this, they insist that I just haven't tried THEIR favorite spot. Ugh...five attempts later, I still don't like it. I was hesitant to try ramen, thinking it was just another name for pho. Besides, when I think of ramen, I think of the messy $.29 packets my kids love. However, I wasn't feeling good one day and decided I needed some soup. I looked at the menu, and it seemed like there was a chance I wouldn't hate it. Well, I found that not only do I not hate, but I actually LOVE it, and I love Ramen KoBo. I've tried the chicken and the pork and just prefer the chicken. I add egg to mine, and I love it spicy. I discovered this place a month ago, and I've been known to eat here twice a week or more. It is a small place and can get busy, so you might have to wait. However, it's really worth it! Also, they're open late, which works for me when I forget to eat dinner and suddenly find that it is after 9pm.
